topicmeta.shortdesc: Elements in DITA are grouped together into a number of categories for organizational and comprehension purposes.
The topic elements are the basic structural building blocks of all information types.
The map elements are the elements used in ditamaps and bookmaps.
The simple block structures within the body of topics are categorized as the body elements.
A topic's metadata is stored in a range of prolog elements.
The domain elements are comprised of a number of separate sets of elements that relate to specific documentation fields.
The elements in the programming domain each have a specific semantic purpose.
The elements in the user interface domain each have a specific semantic purpose.
The elements in the software domain each have a specific semantic purpose.
The elements in the utilities domain each have a specific purpose in defining image map properties.

section.p: The Darwin Information Typing Architecture (DITA) is an XML-based architecture for authoring, producing, and delivering topic-oriented, information-typed content that can be reused and single-sourced in a variety of ways. While DITA historically has been driven by the requirements of large-scale technical documentation authoring, management, and delivery, it is a standard that is applicable to any kind of publication or information that might be presented to readers, including interactive training and educational materials, standards, reports, business documents, trade books, travel and nature guides, and more.

DITA is designed for creating new document types and describing new information domains based on existing types and domains. The process for creating new types and domains is called specialization. Specialization enables the creation of specific, targeted XML grammars that can still use tools and design rules that were developed for more general types and domains; this is similar to how classes in an object-oriented system can inherit the methods of ancestor classes.

Because DITA topics are conforming XML documents, they can be readily viewed, edited, and validated using standard XML tools, although realizing the full potential of DITA requires using DITA-aware tools.

link.desc: Elements in DITA are grouped together into a number of categories for organizational and comprehension purposes.

concept.shortdesc: Elements in DITA are grouped together into a number of categories for organizational and comprehension purposes.

conbody.p: DITA elements can be broadly categorized as follows:

In fact, this is how the DITA Language Reference groups DITA elements. This categorization of the various elements is partly to aid understanding, and partly to make it technically easier for the schema files (DTD and XSD) to be managed.
Elements used within topics can also be differently categorized as block or phrase elements.

link.desc: The topic elements are the basic structural building blocks of all information types.
The map elements are the elements used in ditamaps and bookmaps.
The simple block structures within the body of topics are categorized as the body elements.
A topic's metadata is stored in a range of prolog elements.
The domain elements are comprised of a number of separate sets of elements that relate to specific documentation fields.

concept.shortdesc: The topic elements are the basic structural building blocks of all information types.

conbody.p: The topic elements are the main structural elements of topics. Some topic elements are generic (i.e., inherited from the topic proto information type), while others are specific to the concept, task or reference information types.

Examples of topic elements include:
topic (and concept, task, reference)
titlealts
shortdesc
body (and refbody, conbody, taskbody)
section
example
related-links

link.desc: Elements in DITA are grouped together into a number of categories for organizational and comprehension purposes.
The map elements are the elements used in ditamaps and bookmaps.
The simple block structures within the body of topics are categorized as the body elements.
A topic's metadata is stored in a range of prolog elements.
The domain elements are comprised of a number of separate sets of elements that relate to specific documentation fields.

concept.shortdesc: The map elements are the elements used in ditamaps and bookmaps.

conbody.p: The map elements are a small set of elements, some of which have been specialised into other elements for use in bookmaps.

link.desc: Elements in DITA are grouped together into a number of categories for organizational and comprehension purposes.
The topic elements are the basic structural building blocks of all information types.
The simple block structures within the body of topics are categorized as the body elements.
A topic's metadata is stored in a range of prolog elements.
The domain elements are comprised of a number of separate sets of elements that relate to specific documentation fields.

concept.shortdesc: The simple block structures within the body of topics are categorized as the body elements.

conbody.p: Body elements are the most common content authoring block elements, and include:

link.desc: Elements in DITA are grouped together into a number of categories for organizational and comprehension purposes.
The topic elements are the basic structural building blocks of all information types.
The map elements are the elements used in ditamaps and bookmaps.
A topic's metadata is stored in a range of prolog elements.
The domain elements are comprised of a number of separate sets of elements that relate to specific documentation fields.

concept.shortdesc: A topic's metadata is stored in a range of prolog elements.

conbody.p: The DITA prolog elements contain the main metadata for a topic or collection.
The types of information recorded in the prolog include:

ul.li: permissions for use/management of the content
extensive metadata about the content of the document

link.desc: Elements in DITA are grouped together into a number of categories for organizational and comprehension purposes.
The topic elements are the basic structural building blocks of all information types.
The map elements are the elements used in ditamaps and bookmaps.
The simple block structures within the body of topics are categorized as the body elements.
The domain elements are comprised of a number of separate sets of elements that relate to specific documentation fields.

concept.shortdesc: The domain elements are comprised of a number of separate sets of elements that relate to specific documentation fields.

conbody.p: Remembering that DITA started life within IBM as a tool for creating software and hardware documentation, it shouldn't be a surprise to discover that DITA's base elements reflect that background.
Elements that relate to a particular field (such as software) are called domain elements. The domain elements within DITA are grouped into:

dd.p: generic word-processor like elements used to highlight text
terms and structures related to programming environments
terms and structures related to the operation of a software program
elements that relate to table structures
terms and structures related to a software user interface
elements that don't fit anywhere else!

conbody.p: If you are writing a programmer's reference, you will mainly use elements in the programming domain.
If you are writing a mobile phone user guide, you should avoid using programming domain elements, and mainly use user interface domain elements.

The typographical domain elements are designed to be used only when no semantically-appropriate elements are available and a formatting effect is required. These elements should therefore only be used as a last resort.

link.desc: Elements in DITA are grouped together into a number of categories for organizational and comprehension purposes.
The topic elements are the basic structural building blocks of all information types.
The map elements are the elements used in ditamaps and bookmaps.
The simple block structures within the body of topics are categorized as the body elements.
A topic's metadata is stored in a range of prolog elements.
The elements in the programming domain each have a specific semantic purpose.
The elements in the user interface domain each have a specific semantic purpose.
The elements in the software domain each have a specific semantic purpose.
The elements in the utilities domain each have a specific purpose in defining image map properties.

concept.shortdesc: The elements in the programming domain each have a specific semantic purpose.

conbody.p: Here is a list of elements, their semantic purposes, and an example for each.

dlentry.dd:
API name
Example: Google Maps

code block
Example: dir /s/w/o/p/a:-d

code phrase
Example: dir read *.*lists all files in the current directory that begin with read with any extension.

one of a set of options
Example: Topic can be a concept, or a task, or a reference. Let's prefer task option here.

parameter or argument
Example: Use the env parameter of the "config" command to update to update a field value.

parameter list
Example:
parameter_1 This is the first parameter in the parameter list.
parameter_2 This is the second parameter in the parameter list.
Here's how you can define a parameter list using this tag:

parameter list entry (within parml)
Example:
parameter_1 This is a parameter entry.
Here's how you can use this tag to enter a parameter:

parameter term (within plentry)
Example:
parameter_1 This is the parameter term.
Here's how this tag is used:

parameter definition
Example:
paramter_1 This is the parameter definition.
Here's how this tag is used:

syntax phrase. It is used when a complete syntax diagram is not required, but some of the syntax elements, such as <kwd><oper><delim> are used within the text flow of the topic content.
Example:formatvolumename Here's how this tag is used:

syntax diagram
Example: This is the element container for syntax elements. Here's how this tag is used:

group of syntactic units (used only for syntax diagrams)
Example:
Place your group of syntactic units here. Here's how this tag is used:

choice of a group of syntactic units (used only for syntax diagrams)
Example:
var1 -name Here's how this tag is used:

group of composite syntactic units (used only for syntax diagrams)
Example:
v1 Here's how this tag is used:

fragment of syntax (used only for syntax diagrams)
Example: xyz Here's how this tag is used:

cross-reference to a fragment of syntax diagram
Example: xyz Here's how this tag is used:

block of small pieces of a syntax definition into a larger piece.
Example:
v1variable_name
Here's how this tag is used:

footnote within syntax (syntax note). Use it to explain aspects of the syntax that cannot be expressed in the markup itself.
Example: My first syntax note Here's how this tag can be used:

cross-reference to a syntax note
Example: Here's how this tag can be used:

syntax keyword (used only for syntax diagrams)
Example: CopyFile COPYF

variable that a user must supply, such as their user name or password (used only for syntax diagrams)
Example: input-filename Here's how this tag can be used:

operator character (such as +, -, and =) within syntax
Example: Adding 1 + 2 Here's how this tag can be used:

delimiter characters (such as /, |, and ;) to mark the beginning or end of a section within a syntax diagram.
Example: one | two | three

seperator character within syntax
Example: 1 + ( 2 * 3 ) = 7

seperator character for repeated syntax elements
Example: , This That The other

link.desc: The domain elements are comprised of a number of separate sets of elements that relate to specific documentation fields.
The elements in the user interface domain each have a specific semantic purpose.
The elements in the software domain each have a specific semantic purpose.
The elements in the utilities domain each have a specific purpose in defining image map properties.

concept.shortdesc: The elements in the user interface domain each have a specific semantic purpose.

dlentry.dd:
user interface control element is used to mark up UI controls, such as button names, menu items, and other objects.
Example:
Press the Submit (<uicontrol>)button to submit your form.

window title
Example: The Configure Options window opens with your last set of selections highighted.

menu cascade
Example: To open the Notepad, navigate to Start Programs Accessories Notepad

shortcut
Example: Navigate to Start > Settings to open the system settings.

character (text only) screen

link.desc: The domain elements are comprised of a number of separate sets of elements that relate to specific documentation fields.
The elements in the programming domain each have a specific semantic purpose.
The elements in the software domain each have a specific semantic purpose.
The elements in the utilities domain each have a specific purpose in defining image map properties.

concept.shortdesc: The elements in the software domain each have a specific semantic purpose.

conbody.p: Below are the software domain elements, their semantic purposes, and an example for each.

dlentry.dd:
message phrase
Example: Double-click Setup.exe to begin the installation process.

message block
Example: <msgblock> <title>Warning</title> <msgph>This action cannot be undone. Are you sure you want to proceed?

message number
Example: 401: Unauthorized Access.You don't have permission to access this resource.

command name
Example: To compile the source code, use the javac following by the name of the Java source file.

variable (to be provided by user) name
Example: Use md command following the directory name to create a new directory.

file name or path, or URI
Example: Uncompress the gbbrsh.gz file to the /usr directory.

user input
Example: Instructions to install a software:
Open the terminal window.
Type the following command: sudo apt-get install software-name.
Press Enter to execute the command.
Follow the on-screen instructions to complete the installation.

system output
Example: To access the "sri" directory available in the root directory, first type the comamnd cd.., to go to the root directory. Use this command until you see this path: C:\Users>. Then, type the command cd sri, and hit Enter key. The system takes you to the directory: C:\Users\sri>.

concept.shortdesc: The elements in the utilities domain each have a specific purpose in defining image map properties.

dlentry.dd: client-side image map
hotspot area within an image map
co-ordinates of a hotspot area within an image map
shape of a hotspot area within an image map
